sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving aqueous solutions
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction: 

NaOH(aq) + HCl(aq) → NaCl(aq) + H2O(l) 

Given the following information: 

ΔHf° [NaOH(aq)] = -469.1 kJ/mol 

ΔHf° [HCl(aq)] = -167.2 kJ/mol 

ΔHf° [NaCl(aq)] = -407.3 kJ/mol 

ΔHf° [H2O(l)] = -286 kJ/mol
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following equation:

ΔH° = Σ ΔHf° (products) - Σ ΔHf° (reactants)

For the given reaction:

ΔH° = [ΔHf° (NaCl) + ΔHf° (H2O)] - [ΔHf° (NaOH) + ΔHf° (HCl)]

ΔH° = [(-407.3 kJ/mol) + (-286 kJ/mol)] - [(-469.1 kJ/mol) + (-167.2 kJ/mol)]

ΔH° = (-693.3 kJ/mol) - (-636.3 kJ/mol)

ΔH° = -57 kJ/mol

The standard enthalpy change for the reaction is -57 kJ/mol.
